headline: Computing Looks to Eye-Tracking Tech
summary: Eyes are poised to emerge as a legitimate pointing tool for computers to accompany other methods of interacting with personal gadgets.

headline: Asia in Pictures
summary: India celebrates the Holi festival, a volcano erupts in Indonesia, the U.S. hands over control of a prison to Afghanistan, and more.

headline: Laid-Back Vietnamese
summary: One feels transported to a laid-back beach bungalow at Bunker Vietnamese, a new Queens restaurant with a bamboo wall and decorative clothesline above the front counter.

headline: Ethics Probe Targets Bachmann
summary: The Office of Congressional Ethics is investigating Minnesota Rep. Michele Bachmann, a lawyer representing the Republican lawmaker and 2012 presidential aspirant confirmed Monday.

headline: Howard to Take Over Garden's Sports Division
summary: Plus, the Giants re-sign Kevin Boothe and Pedro Feliciano doesn't make the Mets.

summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of March 26, 2013

headline: DOT Proposes $1.7 Million Fine for Exxon Spill
summary: The Department of Transportation proposed a $1.7 million fine against Exxon Mobil Corp. for failing to properly prepare for what the department says were known flooding risks to one of its pipelines that ruptured in 2011.

headline: Two New Visions of Ellington
summary: Two projects centered on works of Duke Ellington will be unveiled this week in New York.

headline: A Call to Outsource California State Parks
summary: California lawmakers should outsource management of some state parks to cope with chronic under funding, advised an influential state commission.

headline: Wringing Out Laundered Cash
summary: The U.S. is cracking down on alleged money laundering north of the border by people believed to be affiliated with Mexican drug cartels.

headline: At Auction, Diamond Could Fetch $12 Million
summary: A rare, pear-shaped diamond measuring nearly 75 carats will take center stage at Sotheby's Magnificent Jewels auction in New York on April 17, the auction house announced Monday.

headline: Kerry Pleads With Iraq
summary: The strategic cost of Obama's total and election-driven withdrawal.

headline: A Few Goals Would Be Nice
summary: Henrik Lundqvist has played very well of late, but he doesn't have a lot of wins to show for it.

headline: RPI Credibility Falls Off the Mountain
summary: Ranked the nation's best basketball conference according to its Ratings Percentage Index, the Mountain West sent a record five teams to the tournament…and went 2-5.

headline: A College Coach With 'Real World' Experience
summary: Florida Gulf Coast coach Andy Enfield did something unusual for a coach: in between stints he took a job in the real world.

headline: When Email Is Part of Treatment
summary: Patients love it. Physicians find it often saves them time and money. So why aren't more doctors emailing with their patients?

headline: Board Pay Adds Fuel to Hess Battle
summary: The proxy battle for control of Hess Corp. isn't just about who should sit on the energy company's board but also how the directors should be paid.

headline: No Sign of Struggle in Tycoon's Death
summary: Deceased Russian tycoon Boris Berezovsky died in a manner "consistent with hanging," British police said in a brief statement Monday.

headline: Russia Raids Amnesty International
summary: Russian authorities conducted a surprise audit at the Moscow office of human-rights group Amnesty International, the latest move in what activists say is a widening state campaign against nongovernmental organizations.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: How Too Much Comfort Is Killing Us
summary: In a new book, a professor from UCLA's Geffen School of Medicine says modern life has gotten so cozy that even slight adversity sends our survival instincts into dangerous overdrive.

headline: Venezuela to Auction $200 Million of Dollars
summary: The auction is the first test of a new currency mechanism designed to pump dollars into Venezuela's financial system to prop up its currency and alleviate widespread shortages of food and consumer goods.

headline: Theodore Olson and David Boies: Gays Deserve Equal Rights
summary: States shouldn't remain free to discriminate for as long as they wish.

headline: South African Soldiers Killed in Clashes
summary: Clashes with rebels in the Central African Republic left more than a dozen South African soldiers dead, a setback to the government's efforts to broker peace in the continent.

headline: It's Getting Tough to Be a Homebody
summary: To get a sense of where Wall Street is heading, read its lips. Behind closed doors, top bankers sound more like Weight Watchers representatives than swashbuckling financial titans, writes Francesco Guerrera.

headline: A Postscript on Pollard
summary: A spy who betrayed his country and his people is nobody's hero.

headline: A Surf Lovers' Paradise
summary: This suburban home near Auckland, New Zealand, has a curved ceiling, a tropical garden and plenty of surf-themed artwork.

headline: Japanese Investors Start to Cut the Cord
summary: As global investors buy Japanese stocks in a bet the economy will heat up, the country's affluent investors are venturing into global markets at the fastest pace in years.

headline: Egypt Seeks to Arrest Activists
summary: Egypt's public prosecutor issued arrest warrants for five prominent pro-democracy activists on suspicion of inciting violence during weekend rioting, raising fears of a crackdown against opponents of the politically dominant Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Seth Lipsky: A Commission for the Fed's Next 100 Years
summary: The central bank's centennial offers a valuable opportunity to rethink its mandate.

headline: Mortimer Zuckerman: The Great Recession Has Been Followed by the Grand Illusion
summary: Don't be fooled by the latest jobs numbers. The unemployment situation in the U.S. is still dire.

headline: Matthew Lifflander: The Economic Truth About Lying
summary: How much money could be saved if perjurers feared being held accountable for their words?

headline: Spa Town Fights to Keep Job Sources Flowing
summary: Hot Springs, S.D., tries to save two economic pillars: a veterans' hospital and the spa behind the town's name.

headline: Justices Take Affirmative-Action Case
summary: The Supreme Court agreed to review a Michigan constitutional amendment that barred colleges from considering race and gender in admissions decisions.

headline: Bombardier Tightens CSeries Production
summary: Bombardier has condensed its production plans for a second, larger version of its CSeries jetliners to try to keep its tight schedule for the first deliveries of the new planes.

headline: Smokey Robinson: A Most Enduring Miracle
summary: A key architect of the Motown sound on staying relevant and preserving his legacy.

headline: Prehistoric but Far From Primitive
summary: Now at the Field Museum, the most technically accurate reproductions of the Lascaux cave paintings ever done.

headline: Balancing Act for Warner CEO
summary: Warner Bros. new CEO, Kevin Tsujihara, is preparing the company for a radically different digital future while keeping the movie and TV-production company at the top of the Hollywood heap.

headline: Fund Firm at Center of Big Game Hunt
summary: Rival bids for Dell that emerged over the weekend were fueled by Southeastern Asset Management.

headline: U.S. Moves to Dismiss Suit Against Michigan Blue Cross
summary: The Justice Department moved to dismiss its antitrust lawsuit against Blue Cross Blue Shield of Michigan, saying the state resolved the agency's concerns by enacting a law that bans certain deals between insurers and health-care providers.

headline: Kicked Out of Your 401(k)? Don't Let the Cash Sit
summary: A number of firms lately are booting former employees from 401(k) plans.

headline: U.S. Crude Futures Rise
summary: U.S. crude-oil futures prices climbed as investors continued to wager domestic oil prices would increase compared to oil traded overseas.

headline: Virulent Hatreds in the Middle East
summary: Ehud Barak says that the "major challenges in the Middle East today are the failed or failing states armed with thousands of rockets and missiles, the presence of global terror groups such as al Qaeda and, of course, Iran's nuclear weapons programs."

headline: The Unfortunate Postwar Legacy of Harry Dexter White
summary: America's chief delegate to the Bretton Woods conference in 1944, assistant secretary of the Treasury Harry Dexter White, was a spy for the Soviet Union.

headline: Endless Foreign Aid to Jordan Is Losing Policy for U.S.
summary: David Schenker's March 21 op-ed "Saving Jordan's King Abdullah" ends by suggesting that a failure to "save" the king "would be decidedly less advantageous to U.S. interests."

headline: Common Ground on Energy
summary: George P. Shultz and Thomas F. Steyer find common ground in a discussion about global warming and politics.

headline: Fracking Rules? Leave Them to the States.
summary: Pennsylvania Gov. Thomas W. Corbett on regulating a booming industry.

headline: Coffee Industry Seeks New Futures for High-Quality Beans
summary: The coffee industry is trying to launch futures contracts aimed at buyers and sellers of high-quality beans that could be traded as early as next year.

headline: Jean-Louis Dupont: Football's Anticompetitive Streak
summary: Some of Europe's biggest clubs are, unsurprisingly, supporting rules that entrench their dominance.

headline: In Praise of Kinship
summary: You don't have to be a relativist to see that one-size individualism can't fit all cultures, or that clannish bonds are often deeply fulfilling. Felipe Fernández-Armesto reviews Mark S. Weiner's "The Rule of Clans."

headline: Photos of the Day: March 25
summary: In today's photos, a girl poses with a butterfly in London, Spaniards hold Holy Week processions, people apply for unemployment benefits in India, and more.

headline: European Markets Fall as Deal Is Weighed
summary: European stocks fell sharply after Jeroen Dijsselbloem, head of the group of euro-zone finance ministers, said the bailout deal given to Cyprus could serve as a template to resolve any future problems with the region's banks.

headline: U.S. Nudges Seoul, Tokyo to Make Up
summary: Japan and South Korea are haltingly moving to mend their bruised relationship, encouraged by U.S. officials eager to maintain a united front of allies as China's influence rises North Korea steps up its belligerence.

headline: Heard on the Street: Gazprom's Eastern Promise Gets Nearer
summary: Is Gazprom's luck changing? Signs of a Chinese deal getting closer should spark investors' interest, but obstacles remain.

headline: Westinghouse Says It Leads in CEZ Nuclear Tender
summary: Westinghouse has the best preliminary offer in the Czech Republic's $10 billion tender to build two new nuclear reactors, the company said, citing results provided by Czech 70% state-owned power company CEZ.

headline: SEC Backs Facebook IPO Payout
summary: The SEC approved Nasdaq's plan to pay brokerage firms as much as $62 million for losses stemming from the bungled Facebook IPO.

headline: U.S. Boosts Defense From North Korea
summary: The Pentagon is preparing to strengthen its missile defense systems on the West Coast in response to increased threats from North Korea.

headline: Brics Are Slow to Co-Invest
summary: Investment among Brics countries remains marginal even as they increase their share of global investment flows, a report shows.

headline: UBS Team on Long Island Joins HighTower
summary: A Melville, N.Y-based team for UBS Wealth Management Americas, MK Wealth Management, has left the large brokerage to join HighTower.

headline: Liberals Find Themselves in Spending Trap
summary: Those on the left have long resisted every effort to rein in the growth of entitlement spending. But that now is crowding out the other programs they love.

headline: Dollar General Profit Rises
summary: Dollar General's fiscal fourth-quarter earnings rose 8.5% from a year-earlier quarter that had been hampered by debt-reduction and other charges. Overall sales inched up 0.5%.

headline: Small Business Must-Reads — Monday, March 25
summary: What you should read today about small business.

headline: Hungary Bank Move Raises Questions
summary: Hungary's new central bank chief doesn't plan to speak with reporters after interest-rate decisions, a break with the long-established practice of his predecessors that has fueled fears that monetary policy-making in the country will become more opaque.

headline: China Steel Output to Plateau
summary: Growth in China's crude-steel production is likely to be moderate compared with the breakneck pace of much of the past decade, the country's top economic-planning agency said.

headline: AstraZeneca Settles Suit
summary: AstraZeneca said it settled a lawsuit in a long-running series of patent cases, in a move that will help safeguard revenue from top-selling drug Crestor until 2016.

headline: Hong Kong Maids Lose Residency Fight
summary: Hong Kong's top court ruled that foreign maids aren't entitled to permanent residency rights, dealing a blow to the thousands of domestic helpers—mostly Filipino and Indonesian—in a case that has divided the city.

headline: Treasurys Claw Back Most Losses
summary: U.S. Treasurys clawed back most of their losses as euphoria over the last-minute bailout deal for Cyprus faded.

headline: Canadian Dollar Boosted by Bailout Deal for Cyprus
summary: The Canadian dollar is starting the week with a rally, outperforming its major currency peers after the weekend's 10-billion euro bailout deal for troubled island nation of Cyprus.

headline: From Oz to Ohio
summary: On April 12, "Crossing Cultures: The Owen and Wagner Collection of Contemporary Aboriginal Australian Art From the Hood Museum of Art" will open in Toledo, Ohio.

headline: Startup Must-Reads — Monday, March 25
summary: What you should read today about startups.

headline: Kentucky Basketball's New Death Star
summary: Dennis K. Berman: While Louisville storms through the NCAA tournament, archrival Kentucky is coldly preparing to reconquer the basketball universe.

headline: Brighter Lights for Town Hall
summary: As Times Square theaters go, the Town Hall is a bit of a wallflower. What it does have is history.

headline: Chevron Unveils Deepwater Discovery in U.S. Gulf
summary: Chevron found more than 400 feet of of oil-bearing rocks about 190 miles off the coast of Louisiana. More work remains to determine the full extent of the discovery.
